chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Knowledge and Wisdom
sanskrit:
पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ।
जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु॥
transliteration:
puṇyo gandhaḥ pṛthivyāṃ ca tejaścāsmi vibhāvasau |
jīvanaṃ sarvabhūteṣu tapaścāsmi tapasviṣu ||
translation: I am the pure fragrance in the earth, and I am the brilliance in fire. I am the life force in all beings, and I am the austerity in ascetics.
commentary:
In this verse, Krishna continues His exposition of how He pervades all of creation through His various manifestations. He identifies Himself with the subtle essence of earth (pure fragrance), the luminous quality of fire (brilliance), the vital principle in all living beings (life force), and the disciplined energy in spiritual practitioners (austerity). These examples demonstrate that the Divine is not separate from creation but is the very essence that gives each element and being its characteristic quality and power.

The verse emphasizes that Krishna is present as the purest and most essential aspect of each element and quality. The 'pure fragrance' (puṇyo gandhaḥ) in earth represents the untainted, natural essence before any corruption or mixture. Similarly, the brilliance in fire, the life in beings, and the discipline in ascetics all represent the highest, most refined manifestation of these qualities. This teaching helps the spiritual aspirant recognize the Divine in the world around them, transforming ordinary perception into a means of remembering God. By understanding that all positive qualities and life-sustaining forces originate from the Supreme, one develops a vision of unity underlying the apparent diversity of creation, which is central to the knowledge (jñāna) and wisdom (vijñāna) that this chapter seeks to impart.
speaker: Krishna
